✅ Correct Answer: D. Does not require functioning pancreatic Beta cells for its action.

403

Adverse reaction of amiodarone include:

A. Photodermatitis.

B. Pneumonitis.

C. Hypothyroidism.

D. All of the above.

Here is the answer to your question:

Question: Adverse reaction of amiodarone include:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung 2024 Reference

A. Photodermatitis

✅ Correct

"The skin deposits result in a photodermatitis and a gray-blue skin discoloration in sun-exposed areas..."301_Katzun Pharm Split_…

B. Pneumonitis

✅ Correct

"Dose-related pulmonary toxicity is the most important adverse effect. Even on a low dose... fatal pulmonary fibrosis may be observed..."301_Katzun Pharm Split_…

C. Hypothyroidism

✅ Correct

"Amiodarone blocks the peripheral conversion of thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3)... Amiodarone may result in hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism."301_Katzun Pharm Split_…

D. All of the above

✅ Correct

Since A, B, and C are all correct, this option is also correct.

 

✅ Correct Answer: D. All of the above.

404

All of the following increased the likelihood of digoxin toxicity except:

A. Increased plasma calcium concentration.

B. Quinidine.

C. Calcium carbonate containing antacids.

D. Antibiotics in 10% of the population.

Here is the evaluation of the options for the question on digoxin toxicity:

Option

Answer

Explanation with Katzung Reference

A. Increased plasma calcium concentration

✅ Correct

“Hypercalcemia increases the risk of digitalis-induced arrhythmias.” This makes it a risk factor for digoxin toxicity1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Quinidine

✅ Correct

“Quinidine: Increased digoxin plasma concentrations; displaces digoxin from tissue binding sites.” Thus, quinidine increases the risk of toxicity1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Calcium carbonate containing antacids

❌ Wrong (Correct answer to the MCQ)

Katzung does not list calcium carbonate antacids among the agents that increase digoxin toxicity. Instead, some substances like kaolin-pectin and sulfasalazine decrease digoxin absorption1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

D. Antibiotics in 10% of the population

✅ Correct

“Macrolide antibiotics... inhibit the elimination of digoxin.” Additionally, gut flora disruption by antibiotics can affect digoxin metabolism, especially in individuals with certain bacterial profiles1801_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: C. Calcium carbonate containing antacids

These do not increase digoxin toxicity and may reduce its absorption, thus decreasing bioavailability.

405

All of the following may cause seizures directly or indirectly except:

A. Hydromorphone.

B. Morphine-3-glucuronide.(M3G)

C. Morphine-6-glucuronide.(M6G)

D. Flumazenil.

You're absolutely right to challenge that — let's carefully reanalyze all four options directly using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

 

✅ Revised Table:

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation with Katzung Reference

A. Hydromorphone

❌ Wrong (i.e., it can cause seizures)

Opioids like hydromorphone can cause seizures, especially at high doses or in renal impairment. This is a class effect, shared with morphine and its metabolites601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Morphine-3-glucuronide (M3G)

❌ Wrong

Katzung states clearly: “M3G lacks analgesic effects, and high levels may cause neuroexcitation and seizures.” — confirming seizure risk601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Morphine-6-glucuronide (M6G)

✅ Correct (i.e., does not cause seizures)

M6G is the active analgesic metabolite. Katzung attributes no neurotoxic or seizure-inducing properties to it.

D. Flumazenil

❌ Wrong

“Seizures may occur following flumazenil administration, especially if a benzodiazepine was taken with tricyclic antidepressants” — clearly confirms seizure risk601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

 

✅ Final Answer:

C. Morphine-6-glucuronide (M6G) — it does not cause seizures.

Thanks for pointing that out — accuracy matters.

406

The adverse effects of captopril include:

A. Hypokalaemia.

B. Increases cholesterol.

C. Polycythaemia.

D. Dry cough.

Here is the evaluation of the options regarding the adverse effects of captopril:

Option

Correct/Incorrect

Explanation with Direct Quote from Katzung

A. Hypokalaemia

❌ Incorrect

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor, which tends to cause hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia. “Toxicity: ... Hyperkalemia, dry cough...”301_Katzun Pharm Split_…

B. Increases cholesterol

❌ Incorrect

There is no mention of captopril causing an increase in cholesterol. This is not a known adverse effect according to Katzung.

C. Polycythaemia

❌ Incorrect

Captopril does not cause polycythemia. No evidence or mention of this adverse effect is found in Katzung.

D. Dry cough

✅ Correct

“Toxicity: ... dry cough...” is a well-known and characteristic adverse effect of ACE inhibitors like captopril due to increased bradykinin301_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

Correct Answer: D. Dry cough

407

Volume of distribution equals:

A. Total amount of drug in the body/plasma concentration.

B. Urine drug concentration/plasma concentration.

C. Dose given/urine concentration.

D. Dose given/plasma concentration.

The correct answer is:

Option

Verdict

Explanation

A. Total amount of drug in the body/plasma concentration

✅ Correct

According to Katzung, “Volume of distribution (V) relates the amount of drug in the body to the concentration of drug (C) in blood or plasma” and is expressed as: V = Amount of drug in body / Plasma concentration (C)1_Katzun Pharm Split_To….

B. Urine drug concentration/plasma concentration

❌ Wrong

This describes a ratio that may be related to renal clearance, not volume of distribution. It is not a valid formula for Vd.

C. Dose given/urine concentration

❌ Wrong

This is unrelated to Vd and has no pharmacokinetic relevance for volume of distribution.

D. Dose given/plasma concentration

❌ Wrong

Although this might seem close, it does not account for how much of the dose remains in the body at the time of measurement. Only the actual amount of drug in the body (not simply the administered dose) divided by plasma concentration gives the correct Vd.

 

So, the correct formula is A. Volume of distribution = Total amount of drug in the body / plasma concentration.

408

Bioavailability is:

A. The difference between the amount of drug absorbed and the amount excreted.

B. The proportion of the changed drug in a formulation that is found in the systemic circulation.

C. The area under the blood concentration-time curve (AUC) is proportional to the extent of bioavailability for a drug if its elimination is first-order.

D. Always identical with different formulations of the same drug.

Here's the evaluation of each option based on Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Correct/Wrong

Explanation

A. The difference between the amount of drug absorbed and the amount excreted.

❌ Wrong

Bioavailability is not about the difference between absorbed and excreted drug. Katzung defines it as “the fraction of unchanged drug reaching the systemic circulation following administration by any route”1_Katzun Pharm Split_To….

B. The proportion of the changed drug in a formulation that is found in the systemic circulation.

❌ Wrong

This is misleading. The correct term is unchanged drug, not “changed.” Katzung clearly states it refers to the unchanged drug reaching the systemic circulation1_Katzun Pharm Split_To….

C. The area under the blood concentration-time curve (AUC) is proportional to the extent of bioavailability for a drug if its elimination is first-order.

✅ Correct

“The area under the blood concentration–time curve (AUC) is proportional to the dose and the extent of bioavailability for a drug if its elimination is first-order”1_Katzun Pharm Split_To….

D. Always identical with different formulations of the same drug.

❌ Wrong

Bioavailability is not always identical between different formulations. Katzung explains how different formulations of the same dose can lead to different durations and levels of action1_Katzun Pharm Split_To….

 

✅ Correct Answer: C

409

Carbidopa is used in the treatment of Parkinson's Dx because:

A. Precursor of L-dopa.

B. Decreased peripheral breakdown of L-dopa.

C. Decreased breakdown of dopamine.

D. Promotes regeneration of dopaminergic neurones.

Here's the evaluation of the MCQ regarding the mechanism of action of carbidopa in Parkinson's disease treatment:

Option

Assessment

Explanation with Quote from Katzung

A. Precursor of L-dopa

❌ Wrong

Carbidopa is not a precursor of L-dopa. It is a peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitor.

B. Decreased peripheral breakdown of L-dopa

✅ Correct

“Carbidopa... a peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitor, which reduces peripheral conversion to dopamine”701_Katzun Pharm Split_…. This allows more L-dopa to reach the CNS.

C. Decreased breakdown of dopamine

❌ Wrong

Carbidopa inhibits conversion of L-dopa to dopamine in the periphery, not the breakdown of dopamine.

D. Promotes regeneration of dopaminergic neurones

❌ Wrong

There is no evidence or mechanism indicating that carbidopa promotes regeneration of neurons.

 

Correct Answer: B. Decreased peripheral breakdown of L-dopa.

410

Differences in the pharmacokinetics may occur in neonates because:

A. They have a higher glomerular filtration rate than adults.

B. Their liver enzyme systems are more active than adults.

C. Protein binding of drugs is increased in the neonate.

D. They have lower gastric acidity and prolonged gastric emptying time than adults.

Here is the evaluation of the options regarding differences in pharmacokinetics in neonates:

Option

Status

Explanation & Katzung Reference

A. They have a higher glomerular filtration rate than adults.

❌ Wrong

"Glomerular filtration in the neonate is only 30–40% of the adult value." Therefore, neonates have a lower, not higher, GFR compared to adults1601_Katzun Pharm Split….

B. Their liver enzyme systems are more active than adults.

❌ Wrong

"Because of the neonate’s decreased ability to metabolize drugs..." and glucuronide formation reaches adult levels only by 3–4 years of age, indicating enzyme activity is lower1601_Katzun Pharm Split….

C. Protein binding of drugs is increased in the neonate.

❌ Wrong

Katzung describes protein binding in neonates as reduced, due to lower levels of albumin and other binding proteins (not shown in the quoted results, but consistent with textbook content).

D. They have lower gastric acidity and prolonged gastric emptying time than adults.

✅ Correct

"Gastric acid secretion... increases gradually over several hours" and "Gastric emptying time is prolonged (up to 6 or 8 hours) in the first days after delivery"1601_Katzun Pharm Split….

 

✅ Correct answer: D.

411

Which of the following pairing of benzodiazepines & their use in epilepsy is INCORRECT?

A. Nitrazepam - Grand Mal seizure.

B. Diazepam - Grand Mal seizure.

C. Lorazepam - Grand Mal seizure.

D. Clonazepam - Absence seizure.

Here is the evaluation of each option using Katzung's Basic & Clinical Pharmacology (2024):

Option

Verdict

Explanation

A. Nitrazepam - Grand Mal seizure

❌ Incorrect

Nitrazepam is primarily used for myoclonic and infantile spasms, not grand mal (tonic-clonic) seizures. Katzung does not mention nitrazepam as a preferred treatment for generalized tonic-clonic seizures601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

B. Diazepam - Grand Mal seizure

✅ Correct

Diazepam is used intravenously as a first-line treatment for status epilepticus, which includes generalized tonic-clonic seizures (i.e., grand mal). It is also used in rectal/nasal forms for acute seizures601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

C. Lorazepam - Grand Mal seizure

✅ Correct

Lorazepam is preferred over diazepam for status epilepticus, especially generalized tonic-clonic (grand mal) seizures, due to its longer duration of action601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

D. Clonazepam - Absence seizure

✅ Correct

Clonazepam is used for absence seizures, especially when other treatments are not suitable. It is also used for myoclonic and atonic seizures601_Katzun Pharm Split_….

 

✅ Correct Answer: A. Nitrazepam - Grand Mal seizure is incorrect (as required by the question asking for the incorrect pairing).
